abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Liao River Basin Project
            for China were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was moderate, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also satisfactory.  Some lessons learned included: the
            project adopted the traditional Bank approach of requiring
            drainage companies to be established in each city, and
            assumed that through technical assistance under the project
            these nascent companies will become autonomous commercially
            oriented enterprises by the end of the project. Significant
            reforms are required in government policies and procedures
            to enable the transfer of government functions to
            enterprises, including existing assets, staff, (as well as
            staff benefits for past service), authority and
            responsibility for decision making, etc. In particular,
            achieving a commercial orientation and autonomous decision
            making takes time for government officials. It is important
            to spell these requirements and steps out clearly and
            reaches stakeholder ownership at appraisal, and also to
            agree on their implementation in a phased manner, with clear
            step-by-step indicators. The project is fortunate in that
            the follow-on project provides an opportunity for
            institutional reforms to be continued over a longer period
            of time. Bank projects in medium sized cities (such as
            Jinzhou, Panjin, and Yingkou) often provide limited service
            coverage at a relatively high cost. Even in China, where
            wastewater charges are levied on all properties, including
            industries which neither receive piped water supply nor
            discharge wastewater into sewers, it has not been possible
            to set high enough tariffs and collect wastewater charges
            from eligible parties to achieve full cost recovery without
            subsidies. Instead of permitting unspecified subsidies to
            make up revenue shortfalls, it will be more effective to
            seek to achieve full cost recovery over a period of time,
            with levels of subsidy being reduced to zero on a specified
            graduated basis over time.

            ASST. PROGRAMS & PM TRAINING,TF025912-PHRD-LIAO RIVER BASIN PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Liao River Basin Project will assist
            in the environmental recovery of, and enhance water quality
            management for an integrated river basin management
            approach, in the Liaoning Province. The components include:
            1) construction of the wastewater interception, and
            treatment plant at Panjin, as well as interceptor sewers,
            and new pumping stations - including modifications to
            existing pumping stations. A sanitary landfill for sludge
            disposal will be in place; 2) wastewater treatment,
            recycling, and process modifications, for the recovery of
            processed raw materials, to obtain lignin products
            (lignosulfonate), a binding material used primarily for zinc
            manufacturing; 3) construction of the wastewater treatment
            plant at Xipaotai, to serve the southern/western catchments
            of Yingkou, which includes as well, interceptor sewers,
            construction, or upgrading of pumping stations, in addition
            to the installation of sanitary landfills; 4) construction
            of a chlorine production facility, based on modern ion
            membrane cell technology. Remedial measures to recover
            mercury will be taken into account, and disbursements will
            be subject to the development of an action plan for
            demolition of the mercury electrolysis facility, and
            satisfactory completion of mercury's remedial measures;
            5) works, and equipment for reinforced concrete pipe
            interceptors along the north bank of the Xiaoling River, a
            wastewater treatment plant, and a sanitary landfill for
            sludge disposal; 6) support for urban management information
            systems on infrastructure planning, and, expansion of
            environmental water, and air quality monitoring, through
            improved monitoring stations; and, 7) sub-loans provision
            for high-environmental impact investments in in-plant
            technology process change, and, support institutional
            strengthening, and training of wastewater companies in
            financial, operational, and managerial capacities.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Liao River Basin Project -
            resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Liao River Basin Project seeks to
            address environmental concerns regarding watewater and
            specified waste disposal in Shenyang, Yingkou, and Jinzhou,
            which will consist of urban wastewater subprojects, paper
            mill industrial wastewater management, and construction of a
            wastewater treatment plant at Xinglongtai, and the relevant
            urban interceptor system. This resettlement action plan
            looks at the reallocation and rehabilitation actions needed
            to ensure that project affected persons (PAPs) will benefit
            from the project, and their living conditions will improve,
            or at least be restored to prior standards. Affected
            productive resources of business and public property,
            infrastructure, and cultural property will be restored by
            the project. Compensations will take the form of land for
            land replacement; residential housing will be compensated at
            replacement costs, or with cash compensation; and crop
            losses will be compensated based on output per hectare
            values. Compensation will also be provided in the form of
            subsidies for moving expenses, income, and/or business
            losses due to resettlement. PAPs will be informed about
            resettlement policies, and procedures, which include
            grievance mechanisms to appeal at the concerned Department.
